product_name: Nikon Z6 Full Frame Mirrorless Camera Body
review: I'm a long-time Nikon user, going back to film camera days. I've eagerly awaited Nikon's first full-frame mirrorless cameras, and the new Z6 exceeds my expectations.,First, this is truly a Nikon. Build quality if outstanding, and the look and feel is 100% Nikon. If you've used a Nikon DSLR, you'l be right at home here. First and foremost, picture quality is just outstanding. Detailed images, with natural colors, especially skin tones. I've always thought Nikon's colors were a standout, and the Z6 continues in this tradition.,There's tons of options for shooting different effects, and the Z6 expands to include many additional filter effects I've not seen on prior high-end DSLRs (you can find these under the "Set Picture Control" option, most easily reached by pressing the "i" button on the back. The touch-screen is a great feature here, it makes navigation from the "i" button quite natural and easy. I didn't notice any banding or moire effects in various outdoor shots at smaller apertures (shooting both the 24-70 Z lens and a number of my older AF-S lense via the excellent FTZ adapter). Hi-ISO performance is stunning. Even at 12,600, there's amazingly little noise in the Z6 images. In sum, the Z6 produces excellent images in either Raw or out-of-camera JPEGs.,Highlights with the Z6 controls and usage are the huge, bright no-lag electronic viewfinder. This is a joy to use! Even in very-dark scenes, the viewfinder shows a bright, clear image, almost like night vision for very dark night scenes. There is truly no discernable lag here, either.,Nikon *finally* added U1-U2-U3 settings to the program dial, a much better system than the "shooting banks" from prior high-end offerings. This allows you to setup 3 different camera states (I use "landscape", "portrait", and "action") and recall each with a simple turn of the dial. So much easier than the old method.,Many early reviews (especially of the Z7) raised some issues with autofocus, especially in tracking modes of faster-moving subjects. I've just not had issues in this area in a few days of usage of the Z6. The single point modes are great, and cover nearly the entire image area. There's a "nub" controller on the back, perfectly placed under my right thumb, that allows you to move this point easily over your subject. The Z6 was tack-sharp in nearly every photo using this method, especially with the native 24-70 Z lens. The auto modes worked well, too. It's not quite as quick to pickup less-contrasty subject in AF-C modes compared to my D500, but it's pretty close. There is 3D subject-tracking mode under "auto". Press the center OK button, and a white box appears. Move this over your subject (by either re-framing or the nub control), and half-press the shutter. The Z6 will now track this subject throughout the frame. Give a full shutter press when you want to take the shot. The framing box will continue to track the subject, so you can keep taking shots as you like. Work's great. The Z6 uses a combination of shape and color info to recognize the subject, and follows it throughout the frame. To reset the box, you have to hit "ok" again, and you can start again. Easier to use than describe here, actually.,There's just so much more to say about the Z6. I haven't dived into video modes, but all the other reviews say this is an extremely capable video camera. In-body vibration reduction (called IBIS - in body image stabilization) is another game changer on older lenses that lack this feature. Focus peaking (courtesy of the electronic view finder) means use of older, manual focus lenses is quite easy! Between IBIS and focus peaking, those older Nikon telephotos are starting to look like a real bargain.,Mirrorless really is a game changer, and Nikon's first full-frame versions are an outstanding advance. So many features here: in-body stabilization, autofocus covering nearly the entire frame, an outstanding, high-res and no-lag viewfinder, tons of picture and shooting options, it all adds up to a highly recommended camera in a great, compact form.,I'm not selling my D810 or D500 just yet, but the Z6 has become my go-to camera for most usage (I'm still shooting wildlife on the D500). Well done, Nikon!

product_name: Nikon Z6 Full Frame Mirrorless Camera Body
review: I shoot the northern lights weekly and sometimes nightly for 8 months a year. I purchased this after reading reviews and seeing test images at high ISO level with the expectation that the noise / grainly levels would be better by about 1 stop over the Nikon D610 which I'm coming from. From my experience, this is true and the image quality is fantastic. This is a great camera for low light, astro/ northern lights work based on the output. The low light video is sensitive enough to film the northern lights in real time and the digital viewfinder helps you set the correct exposure the first time when the lights are bright. When they are very dim the view finger doesn't seem to pick them up at all.,Here are some of the negatives that I expected going in and I have taken no stars off for:,-Less than stellar battery life,-XQD card slot (I had to pay 120 dollars for my card, my sd cards are 20-30 dollars normally),-needs an adapter for f mount lens,-3rd party batteries don't work (yet perhaps some will be engineered in the future),Here are the problems that I have had that I did not expect starting with the most annoying and it really distracts from the user experience massively:,- Every time I put it on a 2-second timer delay and the camera times out to sleep mode it wakes up out of it, and every time I shut off the camera in 2-second timer delay mode it turns on out of it! Mind you I exclusively shoot on a tripod on a 2-second timer delay for night shots to give the camera/tripod 2 seconds to settle down after touching it and have no handshake. Every time I have to hit the button and reset it and this is a pain at -20  to -40f in Fairbanks, Alaska in the winter when I don't want my fingers to freeze! My Nikon D610 has a dial for timer delay on the top left and never changes unless I tell it to! This alone is worth minus 2 stars for me, I am considering returning the camera or selling it over this issue. I guess I could get a remote shutter release instead... but this brings me to the next issue.,(If somehow there is a way to have the timer delay stay permanently activated let me know in the comments and I'll add back on 1-2 stars despite the other issues) If this is not the case, Nikon do a firmware update and fix this, for God's sake!,-My 3rd party speed flash won't work on it, it feels like Nikon specifically engineered its new camera to not allow the user to use 3rd party accessories and force you to buy a several hundred dollar flash over my perfectly fine 30 dollar fash. Does this mean if I buy a 3rd party remote shutter release it also won't work to solve the lack of a permanent 2-second timer delay mode? My workaround has been to hand hold the flash (so I don't cause camera shake when triggering it) and manually trigger it. This is not ideal and freezes my fingers further in the sub-arctic of Alaska. I use the flash for aurora portraits.,-Every time the camera goes to sleep or is shut off the aperture rings stop down to the smallest aperture. I shoot wide open or almost wide open on all my shots so when I turn it back on the aperture blades open up again, will this cause excessive wear and tear on the aperture blades and motor and break my lenses? I do not know but it worries me. I wish the blades stayed in sleep mode exactly where they were when it went to sleep / was shut off at.,-Lightroom will not detect any of my lenses for the lens profile correction (I am only using the adapter). This includes sigma, rokinon, and tamron. I have not tested to see if Lightroom will detect my lenses shot on a Nikon brand lens through the adapter yet. This isn't that big of a deal but all the annoying things add up to a frustrating user experience.,-For extreme low light situations, the digital viewfinder is a negative. You can use the optical one on the Nikon D610 to compose a shot with almost zero light by using subtle silhouettes and shadows but with the Z6 you get all black if its dark enough. This means you have to take a few test shots and adjust your camera to the right composition based on them, this further chews up the already weak battery performance and takes up more time which causes fingers to freeze more in the cold.

product_name: Nikon Z6 Full Frame Mirrorless Camera Body
review: These are my first impressions with the Nikon Z6.  I will update this review as I learn more:,I loved shooting the Fuji X100 series for it's light weight and simple UI.  But The ultimate shooting experience has always been with my Nikons.  When we got focus peaking and meaningful fps with the D850 I was happy, sold the X100T, and have been happily gripping my D850 wherever I go with the lightweight 35mm 1.8 and a 70-200 f4.  I toss in the 20mm 1.8G and 300mm PF when I travel and keep the 60mm and 105mm macros handy, as needed.  Been shooting Nikon since the D1, then D70, D200, D600, and now the current generation (as of Nov 2018).,(I will need to test the new diffraction compensation mode (leaving off for now), and how this might interact with the AA filter, vs the D850),Onto the camera:,The Z6 takes great pictures.  I attached two ISO 25600 (insane!) pics to this review, edited in camera to jpeg normal.  Pics of the kids look even better and I'm looking forward to attaching this to my telescope and 20mm for nightscapes.  Nikon image quality.  2 Thumbs, all the way up.,Handling: Left hand is fine.  Play and delete buttons are top back left.  Mode dial requires a push of the center button to turn.  Nothing to see here, folks.  It's fine.,Right hand: It's OK.  New layout, which is ok.  AF-On and joystick nub are where they should be.  As is D-pad - as accustomed as I am  to the DSLRs I found these three important controls well placed. The challenge was with the 4 lowest buttons.  As it is now, I find myself looking at those (menu, shooting mode, + and -).  If I wasn't programmed for my DSLRs I am sure this wouldn't be an issue - there is no perfect layout for everyone and the camera makers do their best.  It's different from my D850, as it should be.  I'd have tried to do things a little differently but Nikon didn't ask me.  :)  Otherwise, I like the grip.  I wear small or medium size adult male gloves, and my hand fits perfectly over the grip and finding the AF-On button with my thumb is comfortable.,I usually utilize the depth of preview button on my DSLRs.  Doing so here seems pointless/useless so I will make that button do something else.  For now I have it set to change focusing modes, as it is quicker than using the i menu.  Second front button is set to "My Menu" which works for me.,Ergonomics: I usually use a Fusion Photo Gear plate with a Herringbone Hand Grip and Black Rapid sling straps.  The plates and hand grip don' fit or feel right, which has sent me on a wild goose chase. For now I have a plate on that is compatible.  Will update this once I find a proper solution.  The problem is the FTZ adapter gets in the way of all the various plates I have in inventory.  Something functional will come along, but in the meantime I am hacking things together.  Since it's so light, I added a leather wrist strap to the grip side for when the strap isn't needed but I want to keep the camera secure to my body.,Usage: I'll use the FTZ but I won't like it.  It works. But it feels weird and adds odd length.  My 70-200 f4 chirps and creaks something odd while in continuous AF mode, hunting within a certain zone.  75% seem to be in focus, at ISO 21500.  The 70-300 AF-P seems to move similarly, albeit much more quietly.  Same hit rate.  But it was dark when  I tested.,Will keep an eye on this because the d850 nails these lenses in the dark.  Will have to test with some nightscapes and parties.,Menus are familiar.  If anyone knows how to make the ISO move in 1 stop increments, please lmk.  I either keep glossing over it, or it isn't there.  :/,The usable AF points over the whole frame: genius.  Finally.  Well done, Nikon.,Weight and Carrying: Love the light weight of the Z6 with the 35mm S lens.  This is why I could leave the Fuji X100 - the kit is larger but not obnoxious and the lens and image quality will keep me coming back for more.  For travel, I'm happy with this combo.  With the 70-200or300, even more so.  Will be nice to have native lenses at some point, though.,4 stars until the lenses come, and we all learn more about the Autofocus system.  I appreciate what the FTZ adapter is supposed to accomplish but I just don't like it in af-c with the 70-200 f4.  I had big hopes here, and maybe I have to better understand the focus system.  Hopefully this gets sorted out via firmware updates, if not in a re-education of how to use the AF system.  Chasing kids, pets, birds, and such is so easy with the 3D tracking on DSLRs that it became my default AF mode.  Yes, I am spoiled, but it really is that fast and useful.  That said, there's nothing really wrong with the Z6 autofocus system.  I believe it works as it was designed, and we can auto-track just as the manual describes.  It's the extra step it takes to get there.  If 4.5 stars were an option, then that's what I would rate it.

product_name: Nikon Z6 Full Frame Mirrorless Camera Body
review: I was hoping for this to weigh less than a typical SLR. I have a Nikon D300s and needed something that shot the same quality but lighter. Sadly, this wasn’t it. It isn’t worth the money to have something pretty much the same weight but negligible in terms of quality of phots, for what I do with them at the least. I’m going to wait till technology gets better and these things go lighter.

product_name: Nikon Z6 Full Frame Mirrorless Camera Body
review: Autofocus is terrible.,Reviewing images I can see the red box was placed on the subject and still it recorded the image out of focus. I went to a Nikon event and had the Nikon representative check the settings and aimed it at him. Most of the images were still out of focus. After a few tries he told me that their photographers do not use face detection and just shoot single point. We tried that and it was better, but at 1 to 1, the focus was still off. If you have a patient subject you can get your shot. The idea of upgrading is to get something better than what you had. Lets be honest, any experienced photographer has a pretty good idea how the image will look with a light meter. EVF will not dramatically change your results. Having a good autofocus will dramatically change you results. Equate it to a Ferrari with bald and brittle tires. If your careful and go slow you can keep it on the road. You could have kept a Ford Pinto on the road and also bought a house to drive home to. I admit the Ferrari is beautiful and that is what you get here.,Colors and noise are rendered beautifully, but that was also the case with the D750. If you think a splash of water will not kill a D750, you are mistaken. If this camera has the same sealing it means lens release button has no gasket so...,I was truly disappointed. I wanted to love this camera, maybe that is why I was so disappointed when it would not let me.

product_name: Nikon Z6 Full Frame Mirrorless Camera Body
review: I went from D5000, D600, Fujifilm X100S, X70 to Nikon Z6. Mainly using ultra wide and wide primes. Nikon is clearly on to something though the Z6 design and performance leaves something to be desired for me. Needs a firmware update to fix continuous AF.,Pros:,-Lightweight body,-5-axis IBIS,-Excellent video recording capabilities,-Ergonomics, controls and Fn customization (can set Fn1 to Playback for one handed reviewing),-Responsive touch screen,-3 User modes (though these keep resetting when powering back on so you lose any adjustments made in that mode. You have to save after each adjustment),-USB-C,Cons:,-Play button is on the left (fixed by using an Fn button),-No flip-around screen for selfies or vlogging, like the EOS R (deal breaker for me),-Viewfinder lags when shooting fast,-Prefer a more compact mirrorless FX model without a viewfinder,-No built-in flash (for those emergency fill in shots),-Continuous Autofocus tracking sometimes loses the subject. Seems to work better in video mode than photo,-XQD card is currently pricey. Only 1 slot,-Lack of pro lenses at the moment (f1.4 primes and f4 zooms are nice but we really want f2.8 zooms)

product_name: Nikon Z6 Full Frame Mirrorless Camera Body
review: My first hobbyist camera was the Nikon FE. Since then I have jumped in on only the historic improvements. This is THE latest. I love  the feel of the camera and the quality of the pictures. It is sort of old school in that it’s full frame digital but in the more classic understated body size of the FM and FE. So easy to use that I hardly need the manual. It is is amazing even with my “ old” lenses.

product_name: Nikon Z6 Full Frame Mirrorless Camera Body
review: I'm a beginner photography enthusiast, and was wanting to get my first full frame camera, and boy, I feel like I hit the market at both a great time, but almost overwhelming time with the choices. A few months earlier and my only FF mirrorless choice would have been the Sony, but with the Nikon out, I researched the two extensively. I've seen a lot of of the photography community recommending Sony, but for my purposes, I thought the Nikon was a better fit, and in the past month of using it, I've never regretted going with the Z6. Regarding the camera's auto-focus performance, I've never had issue, but from what I understand, the criticism has centered around fast moving subjects such as wildlife or sports photography, which isn't my game. I am exploring astro, landscape, and street photography, plus just getting some great shots of the family, and it's been on point. Regarding battery life, I'm generally shooting for maybe 2-3 hours at a time and been fine, but did run out of juice on Thanksgiving when I was using it all day and had to take a break to charge it, so I'll prob get an extra battery at some point (baby steps).,Ultimately, I chose this over the A7iii as it seemed like it would be easier to learn for someone newer, and overall, it checked all the right boxes in terms of ease of use, viewfinder, durability/weather-proofing, ergonomics, and picture quality, and I've been enjoying getting myself out of auto mode and exploring the artistic opportunities this camera affords me. I would like to see eye auto-focus come down the road as its available in the A7's and EOSR, but aside from that, I think it's just an awesome tool that you can't go wrong with. Btw, I give two shits about dual slots, but I'm just a hobbyist and not shooting weddings or anything, so is a non-issue for me, but totally get that criticism in its reviews by pros.

product_name: Nikon Z6 Full Frame Mirrorless Camera Body
review: I currently shoot several Nikon bodies so my expectations were high. ( D850, D500, D750)  I actually really love this camera . I bought it for video and I have found myself shooting it for everything. No it does not track like the d500 ! However I have found that single shot focus is the very best mode for even a flying bird. I know that is  not the preferred method but it actually works . Being a long time DSLR shooter I was surprised at how much I have enjoyed the EVF . The images are tack sharp and the ISO performance is outstanding. The Video, well its phenomenal!!  Loving this little camera !!

product_name: Nikon Z6 Full Frame Mirrorless Camera Body
review: For the past 10 years I've been shooting Leica M cameras.  Currently I use an M10.  I also have a Leica CL camera for backup.  Neither camera nor Leica lenses are weather resistant.  For this reason I wanted a camera that I was not afraid to get some rain or snow on.  Hence, the reason for buying the Z6 along with the 35mm Z lens.,Had I not been shooting Leica cameras and lenses (as well as Zeiss lenses) the past 10 year, I would have rated the Nikon Z6 5-star rather than 4-star.  The Z6 camera is a very good camera.  The menu options are not too arcane that I was not able to figure out most of the settings I wanted without having to extensively consult the manual (I did look a few things up but they were easy to find in the manual).,The Nikon 35mm Z lens is good but frankly for the price ($850-ish) the image quality is only average.  Again, if I did not have Leica or Zeiss as a comparison, I would probably have rated this lens 5-star but overall, the Z6 and Z lens are very good but not great.  Great would warrant 5-star but very good is 4-star.,I have not had any of the problems with auto focus that many internet experts report.  For stills and the occasional video clip, the images are fine and the auto focus has performed very well.  I have been impressed by the image color… nicely saturated (better than Leica), decent contrast (not nearly as good as Leica) and decent small detail (again, not as good as Leica).,A lot is made of dynamic range.  I am not a mega pixel examiner and so I find the recent obsession with dynamic range a little over the top.  As long as my main subject is in focus, has good color, sharp detail, I really don't care how many leaves on the bush in the distance I can make out or how much detail in the foreground can be recovered.,So, for still shooting and occasional video recording, the Z6 and 35mm Z lens are highly adequate and will make all but the most discerning shooter very happy.

product_name: Sony DSCW830 20.1 MP Digital Camera with 2.7-Inch LCD (Silver)
review: The shutter speed on this camera is sooooo slow. Turning it on & getting it to focus are painfully slow.  Hope you don't want to take another picture right away, because you are likely to miss your chance due to the extended wait time between taking a picture and the camera being ready to take the next photo. Photo quality is ok. The slowness of the camera is just extremely frustrating.

product_name: Sony DSCW830 20.1 MP Digital Camera with 2.7-Inch LCD (Silver)
review: I liked that the camera was so easy to use and also so portable. It easily fit in my pocket. The videos and photos were pretty good, but I got the camera too close before my trip, so I didn't know how to zoom yet! That would have felt better. But that's me not the camera! It definitely takes better pics than my phone!

product_name: Sony DSCW830 20.1 MP Digital Camera with 2.7-Inch LCD (Silver)
review: I purchased this a few months ago when I was going on a vacation to replace my Canon Sure Shot. I wanted something that was smaller and with higher resolution and zoom. I chose this camera because my first digital camera was a Sony and it took great photos (much better than the Canon I had replaced it with). Well... out of the three digital cameras I have owned this one definitely takes the lowest quality pictures. The pictures seem slightly out of focus, and the colors are bland and not at all vibrant. My iPhone takes much better pictures than this camera!

product_name: Sony DSCW830 20.1 MP Digital Camera with 2.7-Inch LCD (Silver)
review: I bought this for a trip to Scotland. I was very disappointed with the quality of this camera. Landscape photos turned out blurry along the perimeter of the photo and semi clear towards the middle. We eventually gave up on this camera and just started using our phone to take pictures since the phone quality was better. The build quality of this camera also felt very cheap.

product_name: Sony DSCW830 20.1 MP Digital Camera with 2.7-Inch LCD (Silver)
review: This little camera makes it convenient to take pictures but has limitations on flash and focus.  In general it does what it was meant to do and should not be expected to take professional or near professional quality photos.  Action photos are not to be expected either as everything ends up a blur..

product_name: Sony DSCW830 20.1 MP Digital Camera with 2.7-Inch LCD (Silver)
review: It was disappointing that there was no manual with this, and while it can be downloaded (for a fee) it involves several hundred pages.  Not what I will be doing any time soon.  I went to Best Buy and a nice young man spelled it all out for me, taking time to show me exactly how to use all the features even though it was not purchased there.  I did buy the memory stick and a case from him because he was so helpful.  This is an upgrade of a camera I had for several years and I expect the same good results from this one.

product_name: Sony DSCW830 20.1 MP Digital Camera with 2.7-Inch LCD (Silver)
review: I bought this Camera to replace an early version, over 8 years old.  Twice the features plus more than double the megapixels and half the price of my older pocket Camera.  Easy to use, easy to stick in your pocket, and GREAT pictures.

product_name: Sony DSCW830 20.1 MP Digital Camera with 2.7-Inch LCD (Silver)
review: We have this camera where I volunteer and I just loved it and wanted one for myself.  I have been super happy with it.  Takes great pictures and is very compact and easy to carry in my purse.  I just have to remember to leave it at home when I volunteer so we don't get them mixed up.  I highly recommend it!

product_name: Sony DSCW830 20.1 MP Digital Camera with 2.7-Inch LCD (Silver)
review: Great little camera. Super easy to take anywhere. Fits inside a jacket pocket. I put a 128g memory card in mine, reads it fine. The only down side I've seen (not to bad) is the time it takes for the picture to take after you hit the button. I have a baby, and I get a lot of missed faces because of the delay.

product_name: Sony DSCW830 20.1 MP Digital Camera with 2.7-Inch LCD (Silver)
review: Love this camera. Used it all day 4th of July and then took it on a 10-day vacation and, after charging it initially, I only had to charge it one time. Got the SanDisk 32GB card to go with it & took at least 200 photos and all turned out perfectly.  Very easy to use - can snap pictures with one hand and they are easy to download to my computer.

product_name: Sony a7 III Full-Frame Mirrorless Interchangeable-Lens Camera Optical with 3-Inch LCD, Black (ILCE7M3/B)
review: Save yourself some time and skip through the reviewers on here that have given the camera 1 star because Sony did not include a wall charger!  People, we are reviewing the camera not the battery...!!!!  Battery charges on Amazon are 10-12...buy one. :),Anyhow, onto my impressions.  I have an a7r2 which is a great camera as well.  From my perspective I am basically comparing the a73 to the a7r2.,The a73 battery life is awesome for a mirrorless body, it can shoot 700+ jpg images without a charge.  I used to have to carry 5-7 batteries fully charged with my a7r2, but not anymore!,Focus Speed and EYE-AF is snappy and accurate.  I took some test shots indoor at ISO 6400 to 12k with a moving 10 year old and 90% of my shots were in focus.  TOTAL game changer for me with shooting in poorly lit areas and still having sharp image.  I would have never been able to get 90% of my images in focus in a poorly lit room with my a7r2.,ISO perfomance, just lookup some examples on DP Review and other sites.  The ISO literally shocked me when I was reviewing my RAW images in lightroom.  You can shoot at 12k ISO without issues and for casual shots 25k is also usable.  This kicks the a7r2's &^$ in low light and I would even say it is better in low light than the a7s2, images are sharper and color is not muddied on a73 when compared to a7s2 or a7r2.,Color on the new Sony's is also much better and the images produced with the camera are SO sharp and vibrant, that sensor is MAGIC!,No camera is perfect...here are few issue I have that I wish were better.,Menu system is still very confusing but better than a72.,Resolution of the EVF and screen are not as high as I would like.,Screen does not flip out or rotate for video users (I don's shoot video) but still an issue for some.  I have not tested but some people have stated that the camera overheats in some cases when shooting for a prolonged period.,For under 2k this camera delivers on every level.  I have enjoyed it and look forward to getting some amazing images.

product_name: Sony a7 III Full-Frame Mirrorless Interchangeable-Lens Camera Optical with 3-Inch LCD, Black (ILCE7M3/B)
review: Amazing camera!!! Great battery life! I can shoot 4K footage all day with just two batteries.

product_name: Sony a7 III Full-Frame Mirrorless Interchangeable-Lens Camera Optical with 3-Inch LCD, Black (ILCE7M3/B)
review: I really liked this camera but it did freeze a couple of times on me. I had to turn off the camera and let it rest for a bit and then it worked fine again. I think it had more to do with my memory card but just to be certain I returned it. I think this is a nice camera though. It took really nice pictures. I reordered another one and a more advanced memory card and I’m hoping I have a better time.

product_name: Sony a7 III Full-Frame Mirrorless Interchangeable-Lens Camera Optical with 3-Inch LCD, Black (ILCE7M3/B)
review: Don't let the size fool you, this camera is an absolute beast, rivaling even the best DSLRs in every way except battery life (definitely buy at least a dual pack of extra batteries). The menu system can be overwhelming at first, but it's not too bad. FE lenses are still pretty expensive, but should lower in price over time. If you have the money, this is your best choice for a camera for the price.

product_name: Sony a7 III Full-Frame Mirrorless Interchangeable-Lens Camera Optical with 3-Inch LCD, Black (ILCE7M3/B)
review: It is a great camera with such horrible screen. The touch screen is hard to use with terrible translation. The main point I want to say is this expensive camera doesn’t give you a battery charger, if I use cable to charge, it takes at least 5 hours, when I got my products I don’t have any battery at all which makes me so mad but it helps me to control my temper, what a miserly company!

product_name: Sony a7 III Full-Frame Mirrorless Interchangeable-Lens Camera Optical with 3-Inch LCD, Black (ILCE7M3/B)
review: I love this camera. I can shoot video at night, on the street because of how great the high iso performance is. I can take perfect portraits everytime with face recognition... And with the new update that goes beyond humans to even animals.,Sony's color science is improved, although not perfect.

product_name: Sony a7 III Full-Frame Mirrorless Interchangeable-Lens Camera Optical with 3-Inch LCD, Black (ILCE7M3/B)
review: Menus were a lot to go through, I suggest looking at Youtube videos because there are some helpful things to know just from watching them, and this camera is not a point and shoot, it's really a professionals camera, but it does take great photos out of the box.  As for which lens to get, I had great results with the Sony - FE 24-105mm F4 G OSS Standard Zoom Lens.  Cheers and happy picture taking!

product_name: Sony a7 III Full-Frame Mirrorless Interchangeable-Lens Camera Optical with 3-Inch LCD, Black (ILCE7M3/B)
review: This is my first "real" camera and my first experience with photography. This machine is a beast.  I love the way every picture comes out and I have so much to learn I can't imagine what this thing can do with a little more knowledge and experience

product_name: Sony a7 III Full-Frame Mirrorless Interchangeable-Lens Camera Optical with 3-Inch LCD, Black (ILCE7M3/B)
review: Just needed 1 word.,Awesome!!!!!!!!

product_name: Sony a7 III Full-Frame Mirrorless Interchangeable-Lens Camera Optical with 3-Inch LCD, Black (ILCE7M3/B)
review: This camera for the price is so amazing. The new Z battery lasted me full days in Europe taking photos of everything! I would absolutely recommend this camera to anyone. In fact I have already. I completely understand the hype on mirrorless full frame cameras. The amount of light captured in low light situations is amazing. The addition of a USB-C port is heaven. Thank you Sony!

product_name: Kodak PIXPRO Friendly Zoom FZ43-BK 16MP Digital Camera with 4X Optical Zoom and 2.7" LCD Screen (Black)
review: It's a nice enough little camera, but it didn't work for my needs. My iPhone zooms in more than this camera did. I'll be returning it and buying a more expensive camera that has more zoom. Might be good for someone who doesn't have a smartphone camera.

product_name: Kodak PIXPRO Friendly Zoom FZ43-BK 16MP Digital Camera with 4X Optical Zoom and 2.7" LCD Screen (Black)
review: wanted a cheap camera that uses AA batteries-- pocket size-- with photo / video-- $65 was in my range-- like it use it daily-- this old man would buy it again

product_name: Kodak PIXPRO Friendly Zoom FZ43-BK 16MP Digital Camera with 4X Optical Zoom and 2.7" LCD Screen (Black)
review: Good camera, but it eats batteries at a raate that makes it hard to cons ider reliable. It will cost you more in batteries than the difference for a higher end camera.

product_name: Kodak PIXPRO Friendly Zoom FZ43-BK 16MP Digital Camera with 4X Optical Zoom and 2.7" LCD Screen (Black)
review: (2) of the cameras wouldn't turn on and the other (1) had a damaged SD card slot.  I have purchased Kodak digital cameras in the past and had good success.  I will not be buying them anymore.

product_name: Kodak PIXPRO Friendly Zoom FZ43-BK 16MP Digital Camera with 4X Optical Zoom and 2.7" LCD Screen (Black)
review: Perfect camera for my granddaughter. Thank you. I know she's  going to love it!

product_name: Kodak PIXPRO Friendly Zoom FZ43-BK 16MP Digital Camera with 4X Optical Zoom and 2.7" LCD Screen (Black)
review: i ordered this twice and the first time the clip was missing for the sd card and the second time the shutter just opened and closed and opened and closed  soo not too happy with this one,thank you

product_name: Kodak PIXPRO Friendly Zoom FZ43-BK 16MP Digital Camera with 4X Optical Zoom and 2.7" LCD Screen (Black)
review: Small, but it works well for my teenager daughter who is interested in photography (for now).  Picture quality is not that great.

product_name: Kodak PIXPRO Friendly Zoom FZ43-BK 16MP Digital Camera with 4X Optical Zoom and 2.7" LCD Screen (Black)
review: twenty years or so ago, my first digital camera was a Kodak easy share. It was a clunky thing.,This is lovely. Nice size. the pics tend toward a panoramic ratio, but I bet I can find that setting.,AAA batteries, and the thing doesn't seem to hog the power like some. Next time I accidentaly drop this into the ocean, I'll look to Kodak for replacement. thanks

product_name: Kodak PIXPRO Friendly Zoom FZ43-BK 16MP Digital Camera with 4X Optical Zoom and 2.7" LCD Screen (Black)
review: Not happy, battery area is constantly coming loose and batteries  fall out, have to manually from menu set close up and flash settings...not user friendly. Batteries do not last long either. Takes good pictures but takes time to get settings the way you want them...everytime

product_name: Kodak PIXPRO Friendly Zoom FZ43-BK 16MP Digital Camera with 4X Optical Zoom and 2.7" LCD Screen (Black)
review: Just wish the instructions had told me to use higher powered batteries.. took it on a trip and regular batteries did not work at all.

product_name: Fujifilm X-T3 Mirrorless Digital Camera (Body Only) - Silver
review: What can I say other than I have never been sorry that I purchased this camera through eBay.  It was definitely a good price and I know with eBay that they have a good return policy if I had needed that.  Thankfully that was not the case and I am learning all the nuances of using this incredible camera.

product_name: Fujifilm X-T3 Mirrorless Digital Camera (Body Only) - Silver
review: This is a great camera for both video and stills, but for some the video in the Fuji opens many doors for aspiring and professional videographers.

product_name: Fujifilm X-T3 Mirrorless Digital Camera (Body Only) - Silver
review: Daunting and then Magnificent!  A brilliant game-changer by fujifilm, I’m so glad I took the jump and I’m never looking back!

product_name: Fujifilm X-T3 Mirrorless Digital Camera (Body Only) - Silver
review: Superb APSC camera.  Great for stills and video.  Nice jpegs right out of camera.  Great lens lineup to choose from.  Well constructed and full featured.  The Fuji XT line finally realized.

product_name: Fujifilm X-T3 Mirrorless Digital Camera (Body Only) - Silver
review: Fantastic camera, moved up from a Canon t2i. Famous Fuji color rendering. Amazing electronics, numerous bells & whistles to customize all your settings. Couldn't be happier I finally made the move to mirrorless. Smaller, lighter and most of all BETTER! You'll get used to it quickly and when you do you'll say why did I hesitate to get a Fuji? No regrets, fun keeping up with the great technology.

product_name: Fujifilm X-T3 Mirrorless Digital Camera (Body Only) - Silver
review: Besides freezing when you connect a monitor using the HDMI port, every other thing is on POINT!

product_name: Fujifilm X-T3 Mirrorless Digital Camera (Body Only) - Silver
review: A lot better than my XT1. The silver accent is beautiful. Phone app integration is also a lot better than previous version. I really enjoy using this camera.

product_name: Fujifilm X-T3 Mirrorless Digital Camera (Body Only) - Silver
review: Honestly, you might not even need the "mirrorless" qualifier. This camera rules.

product_name: Fujifilm X-T3 Mirrorless Digital Camera (Body Only) - Silver
review: Unbelievable pictures would recommend to everyone pro or novice.

product_name: Fujifilm X-T3 Mirrorless Digital Camera (Body Only) - Silver
review: This camera is a dream come true. It arrived in perfect condition and works very well so far. Thank you

product_name: Nikon COOLPIX A10
review: Nice camera

product_name: Nikon COOLPIX A10
review: I HAD ONE LIKE IT AND IT WORE OUT SO BOUGHT ANOTHER THEY ARE SO EASY TO USE AND TAKE A GREAT PICTURE..FOR A SECOND TIME BUYING THIS CAMERA YOU CAN SEE I LOVE IT!!!

product_name: Nikon COOLPIX A10
review: Nice to have a camera that uses 2  AA batteries - so much more convenient

product_name: Nikon COOLPIX A10
review: Flash did not work returned for refund.

product_name: Nikon COOLPIX A10
review: You need to buy the card it advertises to go with this camera. You need it

product_name: Nikon COOLPIX A10
review: bought to replace another like that it uses AA batteries

product_name: Nikon COOLPIX A10
review: Easy to use, pictures not great

product_name: Nikon COOLPIX A10
review: Works great !

product_name: Nikon COOLPIX A10
review: My son loves it. It's his first 'real' camera.

product_name: Nikon COOLPIX A10
review: Good buy,excellent quality

product_name: GordVE 2.7 Inch Digital Camera, HD Camera for Backpacking, Mini Digital Camera Pocket Cameras Digital with Zoom, Compact Cameras for Photography

product_name: PANASONIC LUMIX FZ80 4K Digital Camera, 18.1 Megapixel Video Camera, 60X Zoom DC VARIO 20-1200mm Lens, F2.8-5.9 Aperture, POWER O.I.S. Stabilization, Touch Enabled 3-Inch LCD, Wi-Fi, DC-FZ80K (Black)
review: Wanted better pictures than a cell phone allows. Wanted enough zoom to take pics of kids in football games, or wildlife along the road. We use it in "auto" and the pics are awesome, and with the features this camera has (that we haven't used yet) I can only imagine what it's capable of!

product_name: PANASONIC LUMIX FZ80 4K Digital Camera, 18.1 Megapixel Video Camera, 60X Zoom DC VARIO 20-1200mm Lens, F2.8-5.9 Aperture, POWER O.I.S. Stabilization, Touch Enabled 3-Inch LCD, Wi-Fi, DC-FZ80K (Black)
review: Great features of this camera: 1) the 60X zoom, of course; 2)  one can quickly switch between taking pictures and recording videos by pushing a button; 3) there is very little time between pushing the button and the picture being taken; 4) lots of fun picture effects and pre-set scenes - in fact, probably more than I will ever need; 5) the automated i-mode can produce good pictures in a wide range of settings, and allows for some customization of the shot if desired; 6) the macro feature can get you very close to the subject; 7) the camera can take pictures in RAW mode; 8) it can take panoramic pictures.,Not-so-great features: 1)The display is fixed instead of being able to swivel to different angles, which may make it hard to take pictures holding the camera above the head or of objects on the ground. 2) It takes a while to save the pictures, so if you are taking (with the zoom, of course) a series of pictures of your graduating kid you better stop before the kid gets too close to whomever is handing out the diplomas (thank goodness for school photographers). 3) Sometimes when there are strong variations in illumination in a picture the results can be quite bizarre, such as completely white faces on some people while others close to them look normal. I suspect that using the RAW format would prevent this, but I usually stay in the auto modes.,I am also wondering why all cameras I have used, this one included, seem to have the battery compartment next to the tripod attachment, so that if the battery runs out while the camera is mounted on a tripod one must remove the camera from the tripod to swap batteries.,My previous camera was a Sony Cybershot, which seemed to produce clearer, more detailed pictures. I don't know if this is due to the fact that the Cybershot had great quality optics or to the fact that I am still learning how to best use the LUMIX. I suspect that the LUMIX optics may not be the best, but they are certainly functional. So far, after a couple of months of ownership, I am quite excited about this camera - it is very versatile with a great selection of fun possibilities, such as the "miniature" mode. I have been able to take decent pictures of anything from the moon to bugs to family members. The zoom performs best with a tripod, like all zooms, especially when fully deployed, but the software does a good job compensating for instability when the camera is hand-held. There are better cameras on the market, but this one is a good value for the price, at least in my opinion.

product_name: PANASONIC LUMIX FZ80 4K Digital Camera, 18.1 Megapixel Video Camera, 60X Zoom DC VARIO 20-1200mm Lens, F2.8-5.9 Aperture, POWER O.I.S. Stabilization, Touch Enabled 3-Inch LCD, Wi-Fi, DC-FZ80K (Black)
review: I'll be honest; I don't know anything about cameras and I'm too lazy to take a two year class on taking pictures of my kids...or a flower.  I just wanted something that would take nice photographs from far away, action shots, and general photo taking.  This camera does all of that very easily.,I got tired of going to my kids' school functions with just a 4x zoom camera (or my cell phone) only to get THE WORST PICTURES POSSIBLE!  My oldest son had this graduation ceremony from fifth grade.  I was 200ft away.  They were too far away and the picutres I took closer were so blurry they were unusable.,With this camera, those days are over!  You can zoom in from so far away it's ridiculous!  The nice thing is that they don't seem to lose too much picture quality, either.  The picture quality is fantastic!  I will say this; if you zoom all the way out (or close to it) it gets a little shaky.  You can still take the shot but you might want to use a tripod or brace it on something.,Other than that, pictures come out vibrant and crystal clear, even with kids running at full steam.,I am very happy with this product.  I attached two photos.  The first one is pointed at the moon with no zoom.  The second one was at full zoom.  I had to use a tripod for the second one.

product_name: PANASONIC LUMIX FZ80 4K Digital Camera, 18.1 Megapixel Video Camera, 60X Zoom DC VARIO 20-1200mm Lens, F2.8-5.9 Aperture, POWER O.I.S. Stabilization, Touch Enabled 3-Inch LCD, Wi-Fi, DC-FZ80K (Black)
review: Pros:  Great zoom power. Large aperture which allows allows hand held shots at full zoom and use of filters that reduce one stop or more. Multipoint focus tech' which means shots where there is a lot of sky in the center, the focus defaults to infinity, which is preferred. Cons: Bright red objects (flowers, etc.) in the frame tend to saturate -- I'm working on that.

product_name: PANASONIC LUMIX FZ80 4K Digital Camera, 18.1 Megapixel Video Camera, 60X Zoom DC VARIO 20-1200mm Lens, F2.8-5.9 Aperture, POWER O.I.S. Stabilization, Touch Enabled 3-Inch LCD, Wi-Fi, DC-FZ80K (Black)
review: After several months of shooting daytime and other full light shots with this super zoom camera I decided to take it on a two week tour in Europe- primarily because it weighs about a pound less than my Nikon.  The days there were mostly cloudy and overcast.  While the full sun shots were still good, I think overall the quality of the shots were below average and somewere downright awful.  The camera disappointed me with anything less than full sun.

product_name: PANASONIC LUMIX FZ80 4K Digital Camera, 18.1 Megapixel Video Camera, 60X Zoom DC VARIO 20-1200mm Lens, F2.8-5.9 Aperture, POWER O.I.S. Stabilization, Touch Enabled 3-Inch LCD, Wi-Fi, DC-FZ80K (Black)
review: I just take pictures for my own use.  This camera gives me great pictures.  The image stability for video and high magnification (zoom) is very good.  I took still and video at a robotics world competition at Cobo Hall in Detroit.  This was an indoor arena with good lighting.  I took many pictures and video of fast moving robots.  The images were sharp with great color.  That was done with auto plus and 3 exposures per shot (-2/3, 0, 2/3).  Usually the zero was the best, but a few times one of the other was slightly better (nice).  Very happy with this camera and it cost half of what my previous SLR cost.

product_name: PANASONIC LUMIX FZ80 4K Digital Camera, 18.1 Megapixel Video Camera, 60X Zoom DC VARIO 20-1200mm Lens, F2.8-5.9 Aperture, POWER O.I.S. Stabilization, Touch Enabled 3-Inch LCD, Wi-Fi, DC-FZ80K (Black)
review: I am not a professional photographer so my knowledge of the function specifics of different camera models is limited, but as a photo hobbyist, here is my opinion on the Lumix FZ70...  Love this camera!  My old Lumix bit the dust after a LOT of use and so I upgraded to this newer model.  It's fabulous.  Has the point and shoot (intelligent auto) feature along with some manual capabilities...great for the hobbyist that isn't a professional photographer that knows all the technical aspects of shooting photos.  I like the creative options on this one as well.  I took a handheld close up of the moon (slight shake so it wasn't a clear as if I'd used a tripod) with the super zoom on this camera and was able to see craters in pretty good detail...kids thought that was pretty cool!  My photos have been consistently bright, clear and focused and the video is great too.  I would highly recommend this camera to someone who needs a reliable, quality camera to take photos of their kids, vacation, everyday things...can't speak to the professional capabilities.  :)

product_name: PANASONIC LUMIX FZ80 4K Digital Camera, 18.1 Megapixel Video Camera, 60X Zoom DC VARIO 20-1200mm Lens, F2.8-5.9 Aperture, POWER O.I.S. Stabilization, Touch Enabled 3-Inch LCD, Wi-Fi, DC-FZ80K (Black)
review: This seems like an extremely well made and well thought out camera. I expect to almost always use it on the Intelligent Automatic setting and am mostly impressed with the way that the camera deals with difficult areas of contrast in the picture. I am also impressed with the ability to zoom all the way in on something in good light and still be able to get an acceptable photo without bracing myself or using a tripod. Obviously, bracing or use of a tripod would be better. But this is the test that all my friends wanted to try on the camera and everybody was impressed.

product_name: PANASONIC LUMIX FZ80 4K Digital Camera, 18.1 Megapixel Video Camera, 60X Zoom DC VARIO 20-1200mm Lens, F2.8-5.9 Aperture, POWER O.I.S. Stabilization, Touch Enabled 3-Inch LCD, Wi-Fi, DC-FZ80K (Black)
review: REALLY GOOD!!!  After reading reviews I purchased this camera just to go to Yellowstone. I knew that we wouldn't be able to get real close to the animals & some of the scenery. I had my professional photographer, (daughter), look at the reviews & specs. She said that it would be a good entry level camera. All I'm going to say is that she had my new camera in her hands 80% of the time. The words I heard the most was "I hate this cheap, lite weight camera!!" I think it had something to do with the cost of her cameras & lenses that was in her expensive case for most of the trip.,The biggest down fall that I read about this was the fuzzy pictures. I'm not sure why that happened because there was some amazing photos taken out the side widow at 80 MPH, even zoomed all the way out. Just remember to roll down the window, you get less reflections.,So my unprofessional oppion is buy this lite weight, cheap, entry level, camera if you need to get great long range & close pictures.,  Over 2,000 pictures, 1 drop of 4ft. on cement, battery held up great, just charge every night. Get a large memory card it helps.

product_name: PANASONIC LUMIX FZ80 4K Digital Camera, 18.1 Megapixel Video Camera, 60X Zoom DC VARIO 20-1200mm Lens, F2.8-5.9 Aperture, POWER O.I.S. Stabilization, Touch Enabled 3-Inch LCD, Wi-Fi, DC-FZ80K (Black)
review: Just took some pictures on the new camera.  This camera does so much.  I normally shoot a Nikon D810 but needed a camera that was smaller and lighter and could do many of the things my pro camera does.  Sure, it doesn't have a full sensor, but the pictures seem to be pretty good.  I will be traveling to South America with this camera.  The camera is not very expensive and I am looking forward to seeing what it can do.

Uploading pictures has always been quick and easy. Battery life is way beyond what I ever expected. Great purchase!

No one seems to be able to solve the problem. Don't bother getting it in a kit, there is no use for all the extra crap they throw in there. Go for a Nikon!
